Feedback:
Hi, I am a sessional lecturer at RMIT teaching a post -grad course in News and Communication Theory. I am also researching and writing a book on media interviewing. I do regularly take out books on loan from the Latrobe library using my Caval card because your library (with its history and slightly different acquisition policies) contains some excellent texts.  However, with the increased use of E-books and electronic resources especially those texts that are ONLY available as E-Resources, I now find I am shut out from consulting or researching within those books/texts. This seems deeply anomalous. I do understand the vagaries of licences and copyright etc. but it also seems regressive to have increased online availability but at the same time severely restricted availability for those outside the home university. It seems to fly in the face of the "tradition" of scholarly sharing of information and research that has long underpinned scholarly culture. Is there a solution to this apparent anomaly? Is there a way under the Caval system to allow remote or even on-site access to E-Resources at the Latrobe Library. It certainly seems very strange with the advent of such a plethora of information to "lock up" an increasing range of books/texts within the burgeoning E-Resource system.

Thank you
Response:
Hello Peter,

Thank you for your feedback.  Our licences permit in-library use of our online resources.  There are two walk-in computers set aside for community members, CAVAL borrowers and secondary school students to access the Library's online resources.  Go to the inquiry desk on level one (Melbourne)and ask to use one of thewalk-in computers.  A staff member will log you in.  Printing is not enabled but you can download to an USB or email content to yourself (within copyright requirements).  We are evaluating usage of these walk-in computers and will consider increasing the number.  Your feedback on the walk-in computers (once you have used them) would be appreciated.

Best wishes,

Kerryn Amery, Associate University Librarian - Information Services

Feedback:
So, I tried to use my student card to access the library during extended hours and I couldn't. It did not occur to me that it did not roll over each year.
This is my second student card, which I've had for the last two years, and I also had to re-register the new card. This information, that:

Response:
Hello,

Thank you for your feedback.  The Library team does not monitor computer usage.  We understand that students access information in a variety of formats from film and television content through to games and Facebook for their study and research.  A student watching a football game may be studying Sports Management.  Another watching a documentary or television programme may be viewing a recommended item from their course 'reading list'.  The Library's audiovisual content is increasingly delivered by videostreaming - content that is viewed on computers.  Facebook is used for collaboration, for research, for study and for keeping in touch with family and friends who may be in India or Broken Hill.  All of these uses of library computers are legitimate. 

There is a large bank of stand up computers on level one in the Bundoora Library  which are designed for short term use.  I suggest that you make use of these when you want to print an assignment.  Alternatively, you might consider coming to the Library outside of peak times as many more computers are available at that time.

Best wishes,

Kerryn Amery, Associate University Librarian - Information Services

Feedback:
Hey Library,

After being a long time endnote user I've recently migrated over to Mendeley. This was the best academic decision I have ever made. Everything about Medeley as a reference manager is better than endnote. So much so, I am writing to suggest that the LTU library consider it as the primary tool promoted to students - through installation on university computers and linking from library info pages.

First off Mendeley is FREE, and considering that an endnote student licence is $200 I can only imagine what the institutional rate is. 

They have an active team of developers and are constantly improving their service and adding new features. 

Check out this comparison table:
http://www.mendeley.com/compare-mendeley/

They are more than a reference manager. Mendeley allows users to link with collaborators via groups and shared refs, pdfs, and annotations. They also have facility to share content with class lists - potentially useful given the university's move towards only delivery.

More stuff they do:
http://www.mendeley.com/how-we-help/

For university libraries, they have an institutional edition which allows you to track the most read journals by users in your network. Helping to make smarter purchasing decisions. An institutional package also automatically upgrades the accounts of all university users, allowing extra collaborators to be added to more private groups.
http://www.mendeley.com/mendeley-institutional-edition/

Mendeley is a fantastic resource for students as well as  academic research groups. It is infinitely more user friendly than endnote, has more features, and just works like it is supposed to. Dumping endnote as the university's primary reference manager will save you money and improve the user experience of staff and students.

Mendeley are all about open access, they let users share and annotate pdf content (covered under fair use); they allow you to export your entire library at any time and migrate to any other platform; custom reference style creation is easy through the open source and online visual CSL (citation style language) editor; and an amazing API lets anyone write apps to mine anonymous data for trends.

Please download a copy for yourselves and test it out. 
http://www.mendeley.com/download-mendeley-desktop

Migrating your existing endnote library is super easy: http://support.mendeley.com/customer/portal/articles/227897-how-do-i-import-my-existing-references-from-endnote-

I would have loved this as an undergrad, and I would love to use the expanded team features with my lab.

Cheers,
Adam
Response:
Hello Adam,

Thankyou for your feedback on Mendeley.  I have forwarded your feedback to to the Library team responsible for bibliographic management and asked them to investigate your suggestion.

Best wishes,

Kerryn Amery, Associate University Librarian - Information Services

Feedback: Endnote is a pretty sub-par referencing utility compared to Mendeley and Zotero. Why does the library only provide information and training on the use of one, proprietary, tool?
Response:
Thank-you for your feedback.

There are numerous reference management software packages available and the functionality they offer is constantly changing, so the Library is always open to receiving new feedback about the advantages of one package over another. The University has offered EndNote for many years, since EndNote was assessed as being the best option at the time this decision was first made. The Library has invested time developing support for EndNote and would need to consider issues such as cost if it was to pursue and support other packages.

In previous years the library has compared EndNote with other reference management packages, concentrating mainly on RefWorks although other packages were considered. At that time, EndNote was still considered to be the best option. The Library will definitely consider and note your feedback, however at this time we are not planning to review the reference support package this year.

One of the main reasons why EndNote has been chosen as the best package is that it can support all four of the LTU styles. Other reference management utilities generally support APA, but don’t do so well with LTU’s version of Harvard, Oxford and AGLC. While it’s possible to create custom styles in other packages such as Mendeley, this is a very time-consuming process and the Library doesn’t have the resources to support this.

While the Library doesn’t have the resources to provide training and support for packages such as Mendeley and Zotero on top of EndNote, these free packages can be easily downloaded and installed and students are welcome to use them if they prefer them to EndNote. Supporters of Mendeley and Zotero often state that these packages are far more intuitive to use than EndNote, and if this is true we would expect students could use them with little or no extra support from the Library.

Clayton Bolitho, Faculty Librarian - FSTE, Bendigo Campus

Response: Hi there. The University is aware that the BYOD (bring your own device) policy doesn't support storage or printing very well. Last week ICT held an information forum with the Cisco vendor to discuss requirements relating to this issue and they have been given a lot of information about problems like this which need resolving. That may take some time. The other issue is that the University is working on, is "Virtual Desktop Infrastructure". This will allow connections to a PC from any tablet or other device, that will then support using Microsoft products and other software, as well as storage and printing. This is being trialled at the moment (just on a few PCs in the Library but not from tablets, etc yet) and ICT are looking at rolling this out next semester.  A third issue is that the Library has a solution to USB printing now on levels 1 & 2 in the Library at Bundoora (there are signs indicating which printers support this). Regards, Simon Huggard, Digital Infrastructure Manager.

Registration is automatically sent to Security.  The upload of information is done manually and given the quantity this could take 24 hours to process.  If patrons present after hours to access our extended hour service, as a duty of care we attempt to process registration on the spot. 

Lea Beranek, Collection Delivery & Facilities Manager.

Feedback:
Could you make the postgrad study lounge accessible to honours students? We have to write theses too and most departments have fewer spaces for honours student to study than they do for postgrads.

If the aim of the postgrad study room is to improve the student experience for postgrads, it seems logical to improve the student experience for the cohort most likely to become future post grads. 

Silent study spaces elsewhere in the library are woefully lacking. After hours is even worse, with noisy undergrads monopolising the ground floor to socialise.
Response:
Thank you for your feedback.

Currently the Postgraduate lounge is only available to HDR students.  We have improved our seating space on level 3 which is a "silent" study area.  During our extended library opening hours, the Postgraduate lounge on level 2 is not accessible as we only open level 1 during this period.

We appreciate all feedback and will consider your suggestions when we conduct a review of library space.

Lea Beranek, Collection Delivery & Facilities Manager

Feedback: One scanner in the library is not enough, I needed to scan 30 doccuments to add as apendices for an assignment and was stopped 4 times by people who just had one page to scan. Students shouldn't have to rely on other's being nice for them to have important doccuments scanned when they don't want to go all the way to the student hub. Bring back the old days when there were at least 3 to use.
Response:
Hello

Thank you for your response. There are 3 scanners located in the library.

There is a flatbed scanner hooked up to a computer in the Audio Visual section to rear of library level 2

There are 2 scanners with facilty to scan to USB and Email with a double sided document feeder attached. one is located on level 1 near to printer 8 behind reference collection. The other scanner which is identical the level 1 scanner is located on level 2 in the photocopy room east side. The instructions for scanning are located next to the scanner A5 copies of instructions can be obtained at inquiry counter. Please ask if you require assistance in using the scanner.

To use the Kyocera scanners you will need to swipe your user card however you will not be charged. Once your card is swiped you will have 5 minutes to complete your scan. You may ask why 5 minutes this is to ensure that the document size is not too large for the internal mail system, and you loosing you scanned work. Save or send documents before 5 minutes otherwise you may loose your work. 

Remember to log off after scanning
Name: Stephanie

Feedback:
For the first time I borrowed a book from LRC but missed to return it after  three hours as I needed to travel somewhere and needed to bring the book with me. I definitely needed that book so I had no choice but to keep it until I finished using it. But, after three days, I was surprised with the amount I have to pay for not returning it on time. It costs me $19.50 for one single book. A single small thin size book costs me that much. I realised that it would much wiser to buy a book than borrowing from the library because unexpected circumstance like this could cost me a fortune. 

I was absolutely NOT HAPPY  with this. I was really frustrated. I could not imagine that a library who was suppose to help me in times that I badly needed a help was the one who constituted to my financial problems.  I was wondering if there was someone looking for that book when it was with me. That would give justice to the amount I need to pay. I used the book thatâ€™s why I kept it for that long. Now I have to pay that amount for USING the book. With what happened, one of the implications is itâ€™s good to let the book stay on the shelf than using it. Otherwise, you will be penalised for using it. Another implication is itâ€™s safer not to borrow books from the library. I do not want people from the community to experience what happened to me so I believe they deserve to know this.

I think the system for overdue fines is not fair enough. I received an email regarding a change in the amount of overdue fines but I was not sure if it stated the reason â€œwhyâ€. Every student deserves to know why. If itâ€™s because some students do not return the books on time, please do not let the  rest suffer from the mistakes of others. If itâ€™s because thereâ€™s no enough copies of some books, it is not fair enough to let the students carry the burden. We all deserve improvement.
Name: Quizon Freires

Feedback: I work as an SLA in the library.  I have received several complaints about a recent decision to allow eating and drinking on the 3rd floor of the library. One PhD student is no longer able to work in the library at all as the stench of food makes her nauseous; I have received another complaint about student's work being ruined by coffee stains, or food stains on the books they pick up.  My daughter completed Year 12 last year and is having a 'gap' year; last week she came to work with me as we were attending an event in the evening, and spent some time reading in the library.  She is not particularly 'academically-minded', and doesn't know what she wants to do next year. Nevertheless, she commented that the library is 'ridiculous' - even with earphones she was unable to read a book due to the noise level, and she informed me that such a library would convince her to look at other universities, even though she likes the La Trobe campus and the courses it offers.  Another student told me they had found themselves having to climb over groups of students having a picnic on the 3rd floor, complete with thermoses and hot curries. Personally, as a PhD student I no longer work in the library at all. The books I need are no longer there,it isn't possible to browse the shelves for related books or journals, and with only 9 computers dedicated to postgraduate students and constant noise it is no longer feasible or productive.  This makes a mockery of the Vice-Chancellor's claims that the univeristy wants to attract world-class postgraduate students.  The decision to allow eating and drinking in the library at all is offensive, but to allow it on the one floor that is supposed to be dedicated to study is incomprehensible; a library is not a student common room, and whilst management clearly believe students are not interested in having a place where they can actually work, I can assure you that this is not the case: students have work that they must do, and desperately need a proper space where they can do it.  Furthermore, not a single student had complained to the SLAs that they were not able to eat and drink on the 3rd floor, making the decision to allow it even more incomprehensible. I would appreciate an explanation of the reasoning behind such a bizarre and 'anti-academic' decision, and a list of the studies on which it is based.
Name: Wendy Morrison
Notes: I met with Wendy and had a wide ranging discussion about the library and covered issues including food and drink, noise, the role of the library (Wendy believes the library is now just a study hall), availability of computers of postgraduates in the lounge (Health PhD students are likely to be mature and have less access (funds) to the up-to-date devices and laptops) and much more.  Wendy asked me not to post her comments online.  Kerryn.

Feedback: I spent 1.5 hours today looking for Sylvia Plath's 'Johnny Panic and the Bible of dreams, and other prose writing', call number 821.914 P716j in Bundoora General. I have been looking for this book, which says it's available for over a week now, thinking maybe someone was using it in the library. The 6 times I have checked for it, it wasn't there. Today when I asked the inquiry desk the lady told me it hadn't been borrowed since 2003, but was returned in February this year (she showed me on the computer, it looked confusing). She then said it could have been mis-shelved and to look around the area (something I had already done), alas I went back and looked through the whole row. I found 4 other Sylvia Plath books in the wrong section and placed them on a cart to be re-shelved in the right place. I am super frustrated that I can't find this book, I know it isn't the library's fault, but perhaps it should be listed as missing rather than available, to save other students the hassle I went through, or a new copy could be ordered.
Response:
Thank you for your feedback - we apologise for this confusion re the loan of this book.
We have checked on the shelves and other areas in the library to try and locate this title. Unfortunately, we are unable to locate this title and have indicated on the catalogue that this title is missing. We did notice that you could request this title via the "BONUS" button on the catalogue as this book is available at one of the other university libraries within the BONUS consortium.
If you have a problem with this procedure please talk to the staff at the Inquiry desk.
Lea Beranek, Collection Delivery & Facilities Manager

Name: Damien Pitts

Feedback:
Dear Library Staff,

I would just like to let you know what happened tonight (10/06/13) during the opening time for the extended hours at the library. Upon the entrance into the library at about 5:10pm, I could not find a single spot to sit and plug in my lap-top computer because people left their personal belongings on the tables and chairs before they cleared the library at 5pm. And I am not talking about one or two or three tables, but absolutely at every table, every spot was made seemingly reserved by people who deliberately left their items there. After circling the library a few times in search of a spot, I tried to talk to the person at the front about that, but he just said: "I know," and then just appeared uninterested in talking or responding in any way. So, I left. This is very frustrating and disappointing because I have been a student at Latrobe University for a long time now and I do not mean to grudge over this because my overwhelming experience at the library has been a good one, but this needs to be addressed. Regrettably, this incident has cost me a lot of fuel, money, energy and time, which is highly disappointing.  And it is absolutely fantastic that the library has been open for the extended hours over the course of this semester, but the rules of removing one's belongings when clearing the library at 5pm must be enforced to ensure fairness to everybody, especially on days when high attendance can be anticipated. I was thinking about taking one of the spots anyway, but at the same time I did not want to end up entering into any sort of altercation with anyone in case they protested. I was just too frustrated, and I decided that it is best to go and talk to the staff, but what do you do when the staff ignores you? I've used the extended hours this semester on a few occasions (including the last two nights) and it has never been this busy, but obviously it can happen, and therefore I hope that this will be taken into consideration and addressed in the future.

Thank you for reading this.
Response:
Thank you for your feedback -
Did you try the Collaborative classroom on level 1 - this room is open during extended library hours. We are currently reviewing the extended hour service and will consider your suggestions during this review.
 

We do encourage students to take all belonging with them when clearing the library before extended hour service begins by our announcement over the Public Address system. Library staff also ask students to take their belongings as they are leaving. I will ask staff to be more proactive in this when they are clearing the library.
 

Lea Beranek, Collection Delivery & Facilities Manager
Name: Milos Subotic

Name: Nick Petrakis

Feedback:
Dear library services,

I am currently disgusted at my fellow students general disrespect for the facilities you have provided for us. It is after hours 10.24 pm and I cannot find a single table to use that is not covered in rubbish, empty coffee cups, chip packets, noodle boxes, energy drinks and screwed up balls of paper. The libraries policy clearly states that food is not to be consumed in the library let alone left in it yet to one here appears to be following that rule. As a result it smells bad in here, the tables have coffee stains on them and I feel very sorry for the cleaners. Please ensure this rule is followed in the future and perhaps put people in place to regulate it more stringently. In addition I would also like to express my concern regarding students booking of the additional rooms and spaces provided, certain individuals are booking these out for the entire semester while the rest of the paying student body simply misses out. I would like to suggest perhaps a limit to the number of times in a semester you can book one of these rooms or spaces to that all students can equally benefit from the resources provided.

Regards,

Sarah Ballard
Response:
Hello Sarah,

Thank you for your feedback. Eating and drinking (non alcoholic ) is permitted in the Library.   The Library Statute (2009) does not mention food or drink.  The Library Service Charter sets out what we ask of patrons using the library facilities.  One of these includes responsible disposal of rubbish.  The Library Statute and Service Charter are available on the Library website in the About Us section, click on Policies and procedures to access the documents.  The charter asks that students comply with the library's food and drink requirements.  At Bundoora students can eat and drink but we ask that they dispose of their rubbish in the provided bins.  Our library service at Mildura and Shepparton is housed in TAFE libraries.  Students at that site have to to comply with the TAFE requirements.  The charter also asks that students be considerate and think of others when using library spaces.  Unfortunately this isn't happening.

I understand your frustration with the litter in the library.  On weekdays the cleaning team clean between 4.00 am -8.00 am, at lunchtime and then again between 5.00 and 8.00 pm.  On weekends they clean on Saturday and Sunday morning. Library staff routinely remind students to dispose of their litter when we can but it is a big building with over 2,000 seats. 

There have been a number of discussions about this problem within the library team and other units.  We are investigating strategies to address the litter problem. 

I have forwarded your concerns re the room bookings to Lea Beranek, the manager responsible for the management of group study rooms.  She will investigate.

Lastly, would you like to meet with me over a cup of tea and talk some more about your concerns? 

Best wishes for your studies,

Kerryn Amery,

Associate University Librarian - Information Services

k.amery@latrobe.edu.au

Feedback:
Sorry, one other comment/complaint.

This one is just about restricted opening hours of the library out-of-semester, in regards to post-grad students. (I don't mean all-night access, just the limited "regular" opening hours, particularly the later opening hour [8am] and the limited hours on weekends).

Whilst I appreciate that the majority of library users are probably undergrads who are not around during the semester and summer breaks, there are still many post-grad students around who are using the library facilities. I find that I actually ramp up the work I am doing in these periods, as I am not interrupted by teaching responsibilities.

Would you please consider (maybe for next summer?) keeping the standard library opening hours over the semester breaks, either as "normal" hours or swipe-access extended hours? This would be hugely appreciated by a great number of Post-grad students who continue to work/study throughout the year.

(On a quick side note, would you consider opening up the 2nd floor Post-Grad room during your extended hours in semester?)

Thank you for your time.

Joanne

Hello,

Thank you for your feedback and suggestions.  You use the term 'postgraduate" in your comments.  Do you all postgraduate students - by research and coursework, or are you referring to Higher Degress by Research students?  Did you know that HDR students can use the seminar room on level one during extended hours?  Would this space meet your needs for a designated HDR space during extended hours?

The Library is currently reviewing client services including opening hours.  I have forwarded your comments and suggestions to the review team for discussion and consideration. 

Best wishes,

Kerryn Amery, Associate University Librarian - Information Services

Feedback:
You know what would be super useful? Knowing where free computers are located on campus.
LTU has a centralised login server that communicates with each uniquely numbered computer each time a student attempts to log on.

Melbourne uni uses equivalent data to provide a live summary of the number of currently available computers in any given university location. 

Check it out: http://www.studentit.unimelb.edu.au/findandconnect/findcomputers.html

This is super simple functionality and could even be rendered as a map.

Dear Librarians,
I have requested a number of journal articles via document delivery. Today I received two emails advising me that the articles are available in annexe storage and I would need to complete another form.
I am a bit perplexed why the library staff do not offer this service.
I had to complete the form from scratch, twice - including identification. When I did not enter the 'captcha' code correctly, the drop down boxes were cleared so that when I tried again another error message was displayed. It took me 4 goes to complete one form, then I had to do another one. At least I realised the drop boxes would be cleared.
The problem is, the form is not user-friendly.
It would be preferable to be able to complete this and other forms once logged in to 'My Library' - to avoid having to enter identification details multiple times - with student details automatically populating the fields. Also if the drop boxes could be more stable. I do find the 'captcha' system difficult as my eyesight is not great - and it is difficult to tell the difference between lower case l (L) and upper case I (i). (They look the same in this font). Some other letters are also confusing.
In short, I was annoyed that I was required to fill in ANOTHER form and it did not go at all smoothly. 
I hope you will consider how to improve the process.
Response:
Thank you for your detailed feedback - we will investigate the issues with the request form that you have outlined and attempt to improve the process.

On the ILDDS web page it does alert the patron to the following:

Use the Document Delivery Service to request copies and loans from other libraries. Do not use Document Delivery to request copies from La Trobe University libraries or the Melbourne Annexe, or to request loans that can be obtained via BONUS+.

The reason for this is that your request for material held at the Annexe is handled by the staff at that location - once scanned the document is sent directly to you via email.

Regards

Lea Beranek, Collection Delivery & Facilities Manager

Feedback: There should be people monitoring the computer usage on the second floor - there are many people who don't use the computers for study, leaving others without a computer to do their work. Many people also group to a computer, creating a loud distraction for others. Today I was opposite a group of young women who reached a computer and used it to discuss shopping and makeup prices, which lead to many students who were searching for a computer to wander around the floor. Earlier there was also someone who was playing a shooter game and eating lunch, only getting off when another student approached and stressed how important it was that she finish her assignment that day. Even then he was reluctant to move.
Response:
Anonymous feedback.  The following information was sent to student complaints.

There are 386 student workstations in the Bundoora Library located on three floors. It is not possible to monitor usage of these workstations. The security guard and library staff do monitor noise. This student could have asked the security guard or a library staff member to deal with the noise problem.

The building is equipped with Wifi making it easy for students to connect their tablets, phones and laptops to the network. Lockers in the foyer provide a secure place for students to store and change their devices. Every study desk on level three and the majority of the group study tables and booths are equipped with power outlets. Every group study room and study booth is equipped with a computer and plasma screen to facilitate collaborative learning. A range of printing, photocopying, scanning and audiovisual equipment is available to support study.

Students use the Library's information technology - wifi, workstations to facilitate learning. We also recognise that students, particularly international students use the library's IT to communicate with family and friends, and sometimes for entertainment. The Library team are wary of making judgements about appropriate use of IT. For example, two students were looking at a 'video' game on one of the computers outside my office last night. I spoke to them because they were sharing a headset and the sound of the game was disrupting other students. On first impression you might think that they were simply wasting time but they are studying gaming technology. Facebook, Twitter, Pinterest and other social media are used for 'study purposes'. I use them for work and for pleasure. Watching films, using shopping sites, playing games, etc could be study related and are sometimes linked to from the LMS. Learning happens in all sorts of ways. Sometimes students take a break from writing an essay to surf ebay for 10 minutes - the equivalent of a tea break. I think that's fine. However, Library staff do intervene if we see students watching porn.

I note that the feedback was lodged at 1.00 pm. 10.00 - 3.00 is our busiest time. Wednesday is our busiest day. It's cold outside. The building is full. There are plenty of computers available prior to 10.00 and often after 2.00. Ii is unreasonable to expect that a computer will always be available at any time. Time management and not leaving assessment tasks to the last minute are the student's responsibility. The Bundoora Library is open 24 hours a day Monday to Thursday and until midnight on the remaining days.

Lea Beranek, Collection Delivery & Facilities Manager

Response:
Hello,

Thank you for your feedback; I will pass your comments on to the University's project manager. We have a program of works in place this year to upgrade and maintain the library building. The carpeting project was scheduled for the 2012/2013 holidays but was unfortunately postponed due to issues beyond our control. The work has to be completed now in preparation for major essential building works on level three that are scheduled for the coming summer holidays. This work will require the closure of level three so it is essential that levels one and two are available during that closure. The project team decided that it was preferable to recarpet now rather than later in the semester. The recarpeting will be completed by 20 September 2013.

We apologise for the inconvenience and disruption.
 

Best wishes,

Kerryn Amery, Associate University Librarian - Information Services

Feedback:
To whom it may concern;
I am an international postgraduate student (coursework). I wrote a comment a few months back regarding the limited amount of work space in the library. I didn't receive proper feedback. I was just denied access to the Postgraduate Study area in the second floor due to the fact that I'm not a research student. With all due respect, I believe this makes no sense since I sometimes can't find a table to sit at and I even see many students studying in the floor. Considering the high tuition fees for international students like myself, I believe we should be entitled to a decent work and study space. I look forward to hearing back from you offering a possible solution. Thanks in advance.
Response:
Hello,
Thank you for your feedback. The Postgraduate Study is reserved for Higher Degree by Research students. On level three there are two silent study rooms that are available to all postgraduate students. Entry to these two rooms requires swipe access using your student card. Have you used either of these rooms? I routinely check these rooms and have noticed that there are usually a few spare desks. In addition, there are over 700 silent study desks on level three that you can use.  I routinely check usage of these desks and have noted that there are usually a number of unoccupied desks.  The students sitting on the floor on level two are looking for spaces for group study work not silent study spaces.  The Library team are addressing this demand for more group study options.

Hello,

In 2009, the Melbourne Library had a major renovation.  Kilometres of print journals (now available online) and books were moved out of the building in order to create an additional 800 plus seats.  We now have over 2,000 seats in the Library.  We are a very popular learning space and usage has grown.  Yes, there are  times when most of the group study spaces and computers are in use.  However, during the week there are many times when it is easier to find a group study seat or a computer - before 10.00 am, after 4.00 pm, every evening until 10 pm, Fridays and weekends.  Having said this, the Library Executive continues to explore options for creating more study spaces in the Melbourne and Bendigo libraries and are interested in learning more about students' needs and concerns.  Please ring me if you would like to talk some more about this.

Best wishes,

Kerryn Amery, Associate University Librarian - Information Services

Feedback: I wish to pass on my praise and compliments to the library's customer support staff observed during my recent visits to the library. As a general staff member in Human Resources at La Trobe University for 4 years I have had occasion to borrow only twice from the library. Although an active member of the Yarra Plenty Community Library and therefore familiar with the borrowing process, I still required some support and confirmation of the La Trobe process. Thursday September 12, 2013 I successfully placed a book on hold via self help, however as I had never placed a book on hold before at La Trobe, I sought confirmation of my actions. Karen was most helpful in rechecking the reserved item and affirming that I had completed the process correctly. For completeness of the service, additional information was freely offered, such as how I would be notified when the book was in, that it would be on hold for 7 days and comprehensive directions for pick up. Friday September 20, 2013 The book was due for return, for my pick up from the 15/09/2013 but as I had not received any correspondence I attended the library to see if it was available. Not realising Friday evening is a reduced service I patiently awaited for the opening at 6.15pm only to find the book was not yet on the shelf. Although only 1 young male library staff member on the door he was extremely helpful whilst trying to maintain the security checking. He also advised me of the My Library function for self checking outside of hours - something I was not previously aware of. (Unfortunately, I did not capture his name) Monday September 23, 2013 Unable to attend the library today during business hours, I logged onto My Library this evening and could see that the book was still on hold but without a notification date. I subsequently rang the library and spoke with Robyn who not only checked the reserve shelf for me but then explained the process when the book is not returned by the previous borrower, by the required date. Robyn also looked at options for reserving other copies. My experience during recent visits to the library have been both positive and supportive and I have been most impressed with the quality and extent of the customer service offered. We often do not praise our colleagues enough for their dedicated work and client focused service delivery. I am sure your other staff are also of similar standard which is indicative of the quality of service you offer as a whole. Thank you to Karen, Robyn and the man who assisted me Friday evening for making my visit a pleasant and positive experience. I look forward to my next visit to the library.

Feedback:
Do you accept gifts of books? My doctoral thesis is to be published as a paperback.
With no hard bound copies now required, would you accept a copy of my thesis?
Response:
Dear Maree

Hi and thanks for your enquiry about your doctoral thesis.

The Library does accept gifts of books if they conform to our collections policies and do not duplicate materials already in the collection.  We would love to get a copy of your new book once it is published, as I am sure there will be interest in your research. 

The Library will be getting a digital copy of your thesis, which will be lodged in the University repository, Research Online. We are moving away from adding print copies of theses unless there is a compelling reason to add it to the collection, and no longer routinely accept print theses in the collection due to space constraints, and the workload of processing and managing the physical item.  Please get back to me, care of the Library if there is a compelling reason  a print copy should be lodged in the Library.

Best Wishes

Eva Fisch, Collection Development Manager

Feedback:
The noise levels in the library are ridiculous. Although I understand and respect there are signs and a screen explaining the sound levels on each floor of the library these really are not being adhered to by the students to a satisfactory level. 
Today alone, in the silent study area I had 4 different students sitting opposite me on the computer who either had long loud conversations about non-uni related things with friends or long phone conversations. Response:
Hello,

Thank you for your feedback and for sharing your difficulties with noise in Bundoora Library.  A security guard patrols each floor of the Library every 20 minutes.  Library staff, including myself, routinely walk around the library and speak to students about noise and behaviour issues.  I note from your feedback that you are complaining about noise after 6.00 pm.  The security guard continues to patrol after 6.00 pm but only a small number of Library staff are in the building after 6.00 pm. 

I encourage you to report problems with noise to the Library staff or Security.  There are phones on every level that provide direct access to Security and Library staff.  Alternatively you can use the chat service on the Library website to alert us to problems.  This is staffed until 5.00 pm but we are considering extending these hours in 2014.  The staff member on chat will immediately alert Security that there is a problem.

There are silent zone signs in every study desk on level three and above the computer workstations on level three.  I have discussed your feedback with the building coordinator and we are investigating options for better managing noise levels in the Library.  We will consider your suggestions as part of our investigation.

Best wishes,

Kerryn Amery, Associate University Librarian - Information Services

Name: Courtney

Feedback: The noise level of the library is getting very tiring. Every day I seem to attract groups of people who meet under the guise of 'group work/study' who doing nothing but socialise for hours, shouting, swearing and laughing. I understand the higher levels get quieter but the layout and access to desks and powerpoints for laptop users is best on the ground floor. I'd like to see a minimum level of noise enforced by library staff for the benefit of those who use the library for the purpose it was designed.
Response:
Hello,

Thank you for your feedback.  I'm sorry that you have have experienced difficulties when studying on level one. 

The Library is designed as three study zones.  Level one is for group study and discussion.  The furniture and layout facilitate group activities.  Level two is for quieter study - both group and individual study.  Some areas of this floor can be quite noisy at times and we are investigating strategies to better manage the noise in those areas and to provide more spaces for individuals and students wishing to study in pairs.  Level three is a silent zone with over 700 individual study desks.  These study desks have power points and are large enough to enable a student to use their laptop and spread out their books and notebooks. 

I encourage you to make use of level three.  I hope that you will find that the layout of the study desks support your learning needs.

Please notify security or the Library team if students around you are being disruptive.  There are security phones on each floor with direct access to security and the library front desk.  Simply ask for assistance and someone will come and deal with the situation.  Alternatively, you can use the Library chat service (staffed 11.00 - 5.00 weekdays).  Go to the Library homepage and click on the chat link.  Simply ask for assistance and someone will come asap to deal with any problems.

Please contact me if you would like to discuss your concerns in more detail.

Best wishes,

Kerryn Amery, Associate University Librarian - Information Services
Name: Ash

Response:
Hello,

Thank you for your feedback.  The Library's three zones are designed to meet the different study requirements of LTU students.  The group study spaces on level one and two support students enrolled in courses that include significant amounts of group learning such as the Health common first year.  Many La Trobe subjects now  involve group work.  For most students their study pattern includes times when they need to work in groups and pairs and times where they need to focus and work alone.  The Library design accommodates those differing study requirements.

 As you pointed out, the Library has three zones.  Level one is for discussion and group learning.  Level two is for quieter study.  We are aware that there are problems with the configuration of the furniture on level two and are discussing strategies for addressing these issues. I'd appreciate hearing your suggestions for improving level two.  I'm happy to meet with you to discuss your concerns and suggestions.

Feedback: From: Alan Andrew Sent: Tuesday, 12 November 2013 2:23 PM To: Caroline Ondracek Subject: journals in annexe Thank you for arranging to have the paper I requested from Numerische Mathematik 56 (1990) 735-762 retrieved for me. (Request 11111642431.) Unfortunately the scan I was sent was incomplete. Pages 736 and 737 were missing. Probably it was done in a hurry. It would certainly be useful if I could have these pages as well. I hope you will forgive me if I express some frustration with the current library arrangements. However, it seems to me that this sort of problem would not have happened if it had not been for the puzzling decision to remove nearly all journals from the library. During the many decades I was on the library liaison committee, the main problem we had to deal with was government cutbacks. I was certainly surprised when the library had an unexpected one-off increase in funding and someone decided to spend this money on transforming the library into something more like a club than a library, with a large food outlet, and lots of empty floor space, but hardly any books and even fewer journals. However, I was already emeritus when this happened and so had no say in the decision. Even more surprising has been the choice of the tiny proportion of journals still kept in the library. The usual justification given for keeping journals inaccessible has been that they are available on the internet. They may be available on the internet, but they are not available to us, as the libraryâ€™s subscription allows very limited access. Our subscription for the journal I wanted goes back only to 1997. For some reason, the few journals still available in the library are the most recent issues, which are often precisely those which are available on the internet. The fact that we subscribed to this journal from the start, which was before the university opened, and that it was very highly ranked in the recent ERA exercise (and was also expensive) should have suggested that it was worth having the entire journal available either in the library or through our online subscription. Why is it that the few journals still available in the library are usually precisely those available on the internet with the libraryâ€™s current subscription? Surely it would be better to ensure that the journals that we have already paid for (often paying a very high subscription), but which are not available with our online subscription, are kept in the library. One of the many problems with replacing hard copies with internet subscription is that availability on the internet can often change with little warning. In particular, our Springer subscription now seems of poorer quality than it was a few years ago. Our old subscription allowed us to see citations of individual articles. This facility does not seem available with the new Springer web site. The fact that we can retrieve articles from the annexe is certainly much better than nothing, but it is no substitute for having the journals readily available. The fact that pages may be missing from the scanned copies, as happened in this case, is only one of the disadvantages. The scanned copies are often hard to read, especially near the margin beside the binding (though the paper you sent me was OK in this respect). Also there is always the delay. Also, scanned copies are never of the same quality as the PDFs generally available from the publisher if we have a subscription. I have often heard it said that only â€œlow useâ€ material has been removed. I am not sure how this is measured. I have been a heavy user of the La Trobe University library since 1967, but I cannot recall ever having borrowed a journal, and I have only occasionally borrowed a book, as I have done most of my reading in the library. If usage is measured by counting borrowings, the material I have used may all be considered â€œlow usageâ€. My use of the library was reduced dramatically after the recent changes, not because I stopped wanting to use the journals, but because they were rarely there when I wanted them. In most cases I have just given up when something was unavailable. This has certainly not helped my research. And, like many who retired while still active, I am still trying to continue with my research (and have published 10 papers since I retired, as well as doing a lot of refereeing). Apologies for the gripe. But it would be nice if the journals we have already paid for were easier to retrieve. Alan Andrew (extn 1208, emeritus scholar in mathematics and one of the old timers)
Name: Alan Andrew

Response:
Hello,

Thank you for your feedback. The Library team are keen to receive feedback from Alumni members on how we can improve our services. 

Library journal databases, as you note in your feedback, are licenced. The majority of the vendor's licences restrict usage of the journal database to La Trobe students and staff. The Library team negotiate with vendors to allow alumni access to databases. Most say no. . In the new year we will have  two additional databases to add to the list. One of these is Expanded Academic.  I am unable to give you a date for Expanded Academic to go live as we are having some technical difficulties.

 We will continue to negotiate with vendors to add more databases for Alumni. I have forwarded your other suggestions to the manager leading this project.

Did you know that alumn can access all of the Library's eresources from any of the La Trobe campus libraries. Our licences enable us to provide access to alumni, school and community members from within our buildings. Each Library has one or two computers set aside for non students to access these databases.

You might also consider becoming a member of the State Library and the National Library.  They offer freee membership which entitles members access to a number of databases. 

Best wishes,
 

Kerryn Amery, Associate University Librarian - Information Services

Feedback: Even though I honestly think that giving feedback previously has been a waste of my time, I will try it yet again. Initially it surprised me that you close the library so early during the semester, but the fact that this remains unchanged during the exam period is unbelievable. I wonder if you have ever seen the amount of students that have to cramp themselves in the first floor during after-hours. It strikes me as though this school cuts costs with no regard to students, no matter how illogical this might be or how much it might affect us. As if this wasn't enough, you announce that you're closing 6 times in half an hour, and today in particular someone went by the third floor telling everyone to leave 10 minutes before. I told this person that with all due respect I had heard the previous announcements and that I would leave on time and her answer included the phrase "whatever, we all want to go home, have a good Sunday". I'm sure you must have heard complaints about this general subject before and nothing has happened but hopefully someone someday will care enough to do something about it. I'm sure you will have a perfect justification for this complaint that will make my comments seem unfounded from your point of view but I would ask you to try and see this from a student's point of view, considering the major workload and high stress levels we face during each semester end. Maybe this will encourage you to at least ask your employees to avoid this kind of responses... hopefully something will change. I don't provide an e-mail because I'm not interested in reading explanations as to why things are done incorrectly, I'm only interested in seeing things change. I appreciate your time.
Response:
Hello,

Thank you for your feedback.  I'm a little confused by your comments.  The Library is open 24 hours Monday - Thursday.  The Library closes at midnight on Friday, Saturday and Sunday.  Is your feedback referring to the Friday, Saturday and Sunday hours? 

Yes, I am aware of the use of the Library afterhours. The Library keeps statistics for after-hour usage of the building.  The statistics record every time a student swipes to enter the building.  This enables us to approximate the numbers of students in the building.  We are using these statistics and feedback from students to review our opening hours for 2014.  I would appreciate hearing from you your suggestions for opening hours for 2014.  My details are in my signature.  My email is k.amery@latrobe.edu.au.  Would you be interested in participating in a focus group?  We are looking for students who would like to discuss future planning for the Bundoora Library.

I appreciate that the announcements can be annoying.  Unfortunately, quite a number of students ignore them or cannot hear them because they are wearing headphones. Unlike you, some students can be quite rude to staff who are attempting to empty and close the building on time. I'm sorry that you were upset by the staff member's response.  I will speak to the manager of the team that worked this weekend and ask her to remind her team to be courteous.  I will discuss your comments regarding the frequency of the announcements.

Please do contact me if you would like to discuss your feedback in more detail.

Best wishes,

Kerryn Amery, Associate University Librarian - Information Services

Feedback:
The housing of some collections offsite in the annexe slows the research process significantly.

For example, I make extensive use of a collection of government publications (Commonwealth Record & Ministeral Document Service) for which no searchable index exists. 

When I become aware of an item (eg. speech, press release, etc) that was likely published in this collection I need to oder the entire volume to be delivered from the annexe. This does not typically occour until the next day. 

If for some reason I revieve the wrong volume (which is a regular occourance due to the way they are numbered) or I realise the volume doesn't contain what I'm after, but another one might,  I then need to wait another 24 hours before that volume is transferred to the library.

Offsite storage also leads of a loss of senendipity in the research process, when while searching for a known item you stumble across a related useful, but unknown, resource.
Response:
Dear Tim

Thanks for your feedback to the Library regarding the housing of low use research materials offsite. We appreciate your frustration with researching a topic which relys on consulting print based Government publications, where indexes do not exist, and citations can be incorrect. 

Did you know that the Annexe has a comfortable study accommodation for researchers who wish to make an appointment to consult long runs of titles?  Long Government publications runs can also be requested from the Annexe and within 24 hours they might be viewed in the convenience and comfort of the refurbished study areas in the Library.

I encourage you to inquire about this service if you ever have large amounts to consult, over a few weeks. This may minimise the need for numerous requests, with the wait in between.

The Library only moved the Government Publications collections after careful planning and consultation with the academic community. The Library staff met with staff in every faculty to explain the collection moves and to ask if any specific titles needed to be kept onsite.  Quite a few volumes were retained on open access, however, the titles you mention were not ones we were asked to keep in the main building. 

Thanks again for taking the time to comment on the problems you have been having.  Please feel free to get back to me, or to your Faculty librarian if there are  other problems you are encounter.

Regards

Eva

Eva Fisch
Collection Development Manager

Feedback:
Hi,

I keep reading about the review of opening hours.

I was wondering, what exactly is being reviewed? Will we have an explanation of why times are changed if they are in fact changed?

I understand you have said that the library is open for 17 hours of the day, however, many people work all day. You then need a break after 5pm before starting your studies, so let's say you get started at 7-8. That leaves 4-5 hours to study, which understandably sounds like a lot, but in reality, it is not.

My main question is why is the review being undertaken and what is it involving? Does it involve feedback from students or is it going to be a purely financial decision?
Response:
Hello,

Thank you for your feedback. In 2013, the Library commenced an internal service delivery review and a review of opening hours was part of this service delivery review. The review was conducted within the context of Future Ready, the University’s strategic vision and goals. The review included:
 

• consideration of current services. Were they relevant, still needed? How could they be improved? What services were no longer needed?
• identification of new services that would contribute to the University’s Learning and Teaching, and Research plans
• consideration of staffing resources required to deliver ongoing and new services
• trials of extended opening hours at Mildura - opening on Sunday afternoons and at Bendigo - opening until midnight Monday – Thursday during semester.
• analysis of student feedback and survey data to identify issues, themes and trends pertaining to customer service.
• analysis of statistics by hour, day, week and month – usage of services, number of queries, usage of library buildings and facililties

As a result of this analysis, new opening hours were proposed to ensure that we have opening hours which are consistent with demonstrated student demand. The Library has consulted a range of stakeholders across the campuses regarding the opening hours. These consultations have included the student unions at Wodonga, Bendigo and Melbourne. This week the University Librarian is meeting with representatives from the Melbourne Student Union to discuss their feedback and suggestions.

I encourage you to submit any comments that you would like considered as part of the review via the Feedback link on the Library website or by email to me.

Best wishes,
 

Kerryn Amery, Associate University Librarian - Information Services
Name: Jon

Feedback: Does the library have a legal responsibility to make the collection of books (a university asset) secure? At the moment it is not secure. At the times when the service desks are unstaffed it is very easy to steal books. Can anything be done about this?
Response:
Hello,

Thank you for your feedback.  Yes, the Library has a responsibility to keep assets such as books secure. Any unborrowed book will set off an alarm if the book is taken from the building.. When the service desk is staffed, Library staff are expected to respond to the alarm and check that books have been borrowed. When the service desk is not staffed, security staff on duty are trained by library staff to fulfil this function. At Melbourne, two guards are on duty after hours and are able to watch the exit doors and respond to any alarms. Our aim is to purchase electronic books where possible; this not only increases access to the books for students, but also removes the issue of books going missing.

Best wishes,

Kerryn Amery, Associate University Librarian - Information Services

Feedback:
I wished to scan twenty pages from a reserve item to a PDF file. I tried to use the scanner on Level 2, but it produced an error message saying I should see an attendant. After waiting in line at the single IT support officer on the ground floor for several minutes, I was told to use either the flatbed scanner or the other MFD on the ground floor. There were queues for both, and I chose the flatbed. However, upon opening the software, it became apparent that one could only save files as images, and not combine them into PDFs. I waited in the other queue for the MFD, only to be met with the message that my account was locked and that I should see an attendant. I queued again for IT support, only to be told that I would have to wait ten to fifteen minutes, and that the scanner and photocopier services were overseen by a different area. Since an hour had elapsed since I entered the library, I gave up my attempt to scan the document. I found the staff I dealt with pleasant, and their responses were accurate, if not particularly useful.
I observe that the previous institutions I attended had standardised all their photocopiers to be MFDs, allowing students to print, scan and copy from any device in the library.
My questions are:
Are two MFDs and one ageing flatbed scanner sufficient for La Trobe's only library, especially in light of the tendency for students to prefer to scan readings rather than photocopy them?
Is one IT officer sufficient to meet the needs of the many students that use the library at any one time?
Response:
Hello,

Thank you for your feedback.  I'm sorry that you had such a frustrating experience. 

There are 8 printers, 11 copiers and 2 MFDs located in the Melbourne Library.  These resources will be reviewed at the end of first semester to determine what needs to be replaced and to ascertain if we have the right mix of equipment.  I will ensure that your comments are considered as part of that review.  You may want to contribute additional information to the review.  You can do this by submitting feedback or by emailing me.

Library staff, who are usually in attendance in the Tech Zone on level one of the Library, are available to assist students with printing, copying and scanning.  The IT Student support service is managed by ICT.  I forwarded your feedback to her.  Unfortunately, the service was short staffed that day due to an unexpected absence.  She apologises for any inconvenience that you experienced.

Best wishes,

Kerryn Amery, Associate University Librarian - Information Services

Thanks Jenny! 12:42:56 Jenny: or members of the public can access most of the online resources, but have to come into the library and use specific 'visitor' computers 12:43:02 Jenny: Are you a health organisation? 12:43:31 Emily: I was thinking of arranging access to the Macquarie Dictionary for a youth not-for-profit literary organisation 12:43:39 Emily: Online access, preferably 12:43:50 Emily: Just wanted to test the waters and see if that sort of thing was possible! 12:44:28 Jenny: Sorry doesn't seem to be. But another thing, if there are any Alumni in your organisation, there is an area for that. 12:45:04 Emily: Mm, I am Alumni myself, so may look into that as well. Thanks Jenny - hope you have a good day! :) 12:45:26 Jenny: So - only coming into the library and using specific computers - re the Macquarie Dictionary 12:45:55 Jenny: Alumni membership provides remote access to some databases, but not that one. See the page above for the Alumni bit 12:46:01 Jenny: Is there anything else I can help you with? 12:46:16 Emily: No, that's all. Thanks for that! 12:46:23 Jenny: You're welcome 12:46:27 Jenny: Thanks for chatting. Bye.

Feedback: received via Kerryn after she had answered - Access to Library/Internet 'To Whom It May Concern, I am a first year student who has had to relocate to attend Latrobe Uni Bendigo. I have not yet been able to organise internet at my new residence. At O Week we were advised that there were a number of things that we needed to do before class started in the first week, including a Quiz which was part of our assessment, and that all information will be on the LMS. On the weekend I came to Latrobe Uni Bendigo, I was unable to access the library, printing facilities or power for my computer. The public library was only open till 1 on Saturday. I had some difficulties accessing the Wifi outside of the building and the sunny weather made it difficult for me to view my computer screen. While sitting outside using the Wifi I noticed a number of students trying to access the building to use the facilities. Thankfully the required assessment was waived due to issues with the LMS system. If it was not then I would not have been able to complete this on time. I understand the need for asking students to start preparing before the first week of class, however the tools for preparing were not accessible. I would request that next year the weekend between O week and first week that the library be accessible so that students can do what is required of them.'
Notes: received via Kerryn after she had answered

Feedback: I have an online class on Thursday evenings at 7pm and it would be useful if the library was open past 7pm as myself and other students could use the group study rooms to watch the online lecture.
Response:
Hello,

Thank you for your feedback. I have a few questions.

What is the subject code for your class? Is your class every Thursday evening?  How many Wodonga students attend the class? What is the duration of your class - one hour?  Is your class recorded and available to be viewed at another time?  You have the option to answer these questions via feedback or by emailing me.  Alternatively, you can ring me on 94791928.

Best wishes,

Kerryn Amery, Associate University Librarian - Information Services
Name: Amy Foster

Feedback: I am concerned that our opening hours may not return to closing at 9pm Monday to Thursday. 12 students have queried this with me in the past two weeks because they are upset that we close at 7pm. I have advised them to entertheir comments on this forum but am not sure that they have done so. Closing at 7pm is a clear reduction in service to the students on this campus and fails to meet the "equity" test for our students in comparison to students at Bundoora and Bendigo.
Response:
Hello,

Thank you for your feedback.  Please encourage AW students to enter their feedback so that we can obtain a better understanding of their concerns. Alternatively, they email their concerns to me or to the Wodonga Library manager.  The Library has undertaken a review of Library opening hours based on 2013 usage statistics (queries, numbers of students in the building) and feedback.  The results of the review will be announced soon.

La Trobe provides physical Library services at  five campuses. Opening hours vary across these sites.  Shepparton and Mildura (co-located with TAFE) library buildings and services close at 6.00 pm - weekdays.  Currently, Library services cease at 7.00 pm at Wodonga, Bendigo and Melbourne on weekdays.  The Bendigo and Melbourne library buildings open as a study space between 7.00 pm and midnight.

Best wishes,

Kerryn Amery, Associate University Librarian - Information Services
Name: Kristine Coyle

Feedback: Reading others' feedback is helpful, but it would be more so if the response (at least) was dated. Also the option to sort by campus would make the information more relevent to the reader.
Response:
Hello,

Thank you for your feedback and suggestions which I have forwarded to the staff member who designed and maintains the feedback database.  He will investigate your suggestions.

For your information, feedback is usually answered within 24 hours and frequently on the same day.  Feedback submitted on the weekend is often not answered until Monday morning. This delayed response time for weekend feedback is under review.

The Library team is conscious that students utilise feedback to report problems that require prompt attention.  Staff routinely check feedback throughout the day Monday - Friday and respond as quickly as possible. 

Sometimes feedback is about an issue that requires some investigation such as a technical issue with a library resource, a complaint about a library service or a matter that needs referral such as a building problem.  Where possible, we advise the student who submitted the feedback that we are investigating their issue and will keep them updated of progress, particularly if the issue takes some weeks or even months to resolve.  Having the student's email address makes this process easier but we understand that some students prefer to remain anonymous when submitting feedback.

Sometimes a staff member will ring a student, if the telephone number has been provided, to find out more about their feedback and their suggestions for improvements.  The Library team value opportunities to work collaboratively with students on addressing service or resource issues and developing improvements.

Best wishes,

Kerryn Amery, Associate University Librarian - Information Services

Feedback:
It is not uncommon to bear witness to a constant decline of the academic standards from within this library, and university more generally, but having the postgrad study room reduced to loud consultations has rendered the last of very few available silent study spaces in operable. 
I dislike feeling polarised by being the voice to remonstrate this point.   Nor do I feel this is the 'good student's' responsibility.

Please could you remedy this situation, perhaps by re-categorising the space as 'silent study', and putting up signage accordingly?

After all, I am here to learn, not socialise.  It seems LaTrobe University needs to be reminded of the difference.
Name: Cameron Scott
